topic.title: ENET Overview

body.p: The Ethernet Subsystem (ENET) processes Ethernet frames into 8 groups of datapaths:

ul.li: PHY <-> FlexE <-> MAC <-> OTN packet mapping

body.p: The ENET holds the 10GE, 25GE, 50GE, 100GE, 200GE and 400GE PHYs (PCS and FEC) up to an aggregate bandwidth of 600 Gbps, but limited to 24 links. The PCS uses IEEE802.3 Clause 49 for 10GE, IEEE802.3 Clause 82 for 40GE/100GE and IEEE802.3bs Clause 119 for 25GE/50GE/200GE/400GE. The Reed-Solomon FECs are optionally used for all rates except 10GE.

The ENET supports up to 60 flexible rate clients ranging from 10 Gbps, 40 Gbps and Nx25 Gbps up to 600 Gbps through the usage of FlexE. In the receive direction, the ENET supports de-multiplexing of FlexE clients from up to 6 FlexE groups. For each FlexE PHY of the FlexE groups, framing, deskew and overhead processing is performed. The FlexE management overhead code words are extracted, packetized and sent externally for L2 wrapping before being forwarded to an external FlexE management overhead processor. When terminating FlexE, all clients are first de-multiplexed and then sent for CBR mapping or receive MAC processing. For FlexE aware mapping, unavailable timeslots are optionally removed and the “crunched” stream is sent for efficient CBR mapping.

In the transmit direction, the ENET supports multiplexing of FlexE clients up to 6 FlexE groups. For FlexE aware de-mapping, missing unavailable timeslots are added back to form complete 100GE streams. When creating FlexE groups, all CBR or MAC clients are first multiplexed and bonded over 100G links. FlexE framing and overhead is added for each link. The L2 wrapper generated by the external overhead processor is first removed, the FlexE management overhead is then de-packetized and inserted into the appropriate FlexE overhead code words.

Each FlexE or Ethernet client can be processed by the ENET through a CBR or MAC path connected to a central packet buffer. The ENET has several configurable adaptation functions to enable different OTN mapping by the MAPOTN Subsystem: BMP for 10GE and 25GE Ethernet/FlexE clients, GMP for 100GE Ethernet/FlexE client; GFP for any client rate equal to or below 100 Gbps; IMP/BMP for 10GE/25GE/50GE/200GE/400GE and any FlexE client rate; BMP for FlexE aware transport mapping.

For Ethernet and FlexE clients going through the MAC path, the ENET subsystem performs Ethernet Packet identification, insertion and extraction. Insertion and extraction of packets are done to an internal CPU which may forward them to an external management processor (External CPU) through a GE Ethernet link. Insertion and extraction of control frames is available on both ingress and egress paths. The MAC processes up to 60 flexible rate clients ranging from 10 Gbps to 600 Gbps up to an aggregate bandwidth of 600 Gbps. A rich and complete set of PMONs is provided for the MAC and PCS into both receive and transmit directions.

The ENET subsystem provides hardware functions that assist an internal (i.e., firmware) or external PTP (Precision Timing Protocol, as defined in IEEE 1588v2) processor in performing timing recovery and/or distribution. Boundary Clock (BC), Transparent Clock (TC), and Hybrid BC/TC modes are supported.

For BC operations, received PTP messages are extracted and passed from the ENET subsystem, along with all necessary information (e.g. arrival timestamp), through the SGMII Management port to the external PTP processor. PTP messages to be transmitted by the ENET subsystem are received from the external PTP processor through the SGMII Management port, along with the necessary information (e.g. departure port), inserted into the Ethernet stream, updated appropriately (e.g. timestamped), and then transmitted.

TC operations may also be performed in the same manner as BC operations, with the external PTP processor. However, an optional in-line hardware-only TC mechanism is also available. This mechanism eliminates the need for these in-transit PTP messages to be processed by the external PTP processor, thus dramatically reducing the load on that processor.

Hybrid BC/TC mode enables both operations at the same time. This allows BC-based termination only for the PTP messages addressed to the local Ethernet and/or IP addresses and TC-based transit for all other PTP messages.

PTP-over-Ethernet, PTP-over-UDP-over-IPv4, and PTP-over-UDP-over-IPv6 encapsulations can be simultaneously supported, with 0, 1, or 2 VLAN tags. Peer-to-Peer delay measurement mechanism is supported. End-to-End delay measurement mechanism is supported. One-step and two-step timestamping modes may be selected on a per-port basis.

The ENET subsystem also offers local timing interfaces (IRIG B and clock/data/1PPS) that allow it to synchronize its Time of Day (ToD) and Local PTP Clock to an external timing master and to distribute its ToD to an external timing slave.
